problems.problem: A student stands 30 meters behind a bus, which is initially at rest. At $t=0$, the bus begins moving away from the student with a constant acceleration of $1 \, \text{m/s}^2$. Simultaneously, the student starts running toward the bus at a constant speed of $5 \, \text{m/s}$. Will the student catch the bus?

step_by_step.explanation: Let student start at $x=0$, bus at $x=30$ m. Bus acceleration $a_b = 1 \, \text{m/s}^2$, student speed $v_s = 5 \, \text{m/s}$.

Negative discriminant means student never reaches bus. Minimum gap occurs when $D(t) = 30 + 0.5t^2 - 5t$ is minimized. Derivative: $t - 5 = 0 → t = 5$ s. Minimum gap $D(5) = 17.5$ m, then bus pulls away.

problems.final_answer: No, the student will not catch the bus.

problems.problem: Car A starts from rest and accelerates at $2 \, \text{m/s}^2$. Car B is already moving at $10 \, \text{m/s}$ but does not accelerate. They start at the same position. (a) When will Car A overtake Car B? (b) How far will they have traveled when this happens?

step_by_step.explanation: Car A: starts at rest, acceleration $a_A = 2 \, \text{m/s}^2$. Car B: constant velocity $v_B = 10 \, \text{m/s}$. Both start at same position at $t=0$.

step_by_step.calculation: Car A: $x_A(t) = \frac12 a_A t^2 = t^2$, Car B: $x_B(t) = v_B t = 10t$
Solutions: $t = 0$ (start) or $t = 10$ s. Car A overtakes Car B at $t = 10$ s.

problems.problem: A car is traveling at $30 \, \text{m/s}$ when the driver suddenly sees a red light 60 meters ahead. The driver immediately applies the brakes, producing a constant deceleration of $5 \, \text{m/s}^2$. (a) Can the car stop before reaching the light? (b) If not, how fast will it be going when it reaches the light?

step_by_step.explanation: Initial velocity $v_0 = 30 \, \text{m/s}$, deceleration $a = -5 \, \text{m/s}^2$, distance to light $\Delta x = 60 \, \text{m}$.
Stopping distance $= 90 \, \text{m} > 60 \, \text{m}$, so the car cannot stop before the light.

problems.problem: A rock is thrown horizontally from the top of a tower with an initial speed of $15 \, \text{m/s}$. The height of the tower is 60 meters. (a) How long does it take for the rock to hit the ground? (b) How far from the base of the tower will the rock land?

step_by_step.explanation: Initial horizontal velocity $v_{0x} = 15 \, \text{m/s}$, initial vertical velocity $v_{0y} = 0 \, \text{m/s}$, height $h = 60 \, \text{m}$, $g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2$.

step_by_step.calculation: $y = v_{0y} t + \frac12 g t^2 \Rightarrow 60 = 0 + 4.9 t^2 \Rightarrow t^2 = \frac{60}{4.9} \Rightarrow t \approx 3.5 \, \text{s}$
Horizontal velocity constant: $v_x = 15 \, \text{m/s}$. Range: $x = v_x \cdot t \approx 15 \times 3.5 = 52.5 \, \text{m}$

problems.problem: A ball is projected with an initial velocity of 20 m/s at an angle of 30° from the horizontal. Neglect air resistance. (a) Calculate the horizontal and vertical components of the initial velocity. (b) What is the time of flight? (c) What is the maximum height? (d) What is the range?

A ball is projected with an initial velocity of $20 \, \text{m/s}$ at an angle of $30^\circ$ from the horizontal. Neglect air resistance. (a) Calculate the horizontal and vertical components of the initial velocity. (b) How much time does it take for the ball to reach a height of $5 \, \text{m}$ on the way up? (c) What is the horizontal distance traveled by the ball at this height?

step_by_step.step: Identify the time on the way up
step_by_step.explanation: Two solutions: $t_1 \approx 0.876 \, \text{s}$ (on the way up) and $t_2 \approx 1.165 \, \text{s}$ (on the way down). We use $t_1$.

problems.problem: The position-time graph shown depicts the motion of an object. Which of the following best describes the motion represented by this graph?

step_by_step.explanation: The graph shows a parabolic curve, which is characteristic of motion with constant acceleration.
The slope starts positive (positive velocity), decreases to zero at the peak (momentary stop), then becomes negative (negative velocity).

step_by_step.calculation: For position-time graphs, a parabola indicates constant acceleration. Since the parabola opens downward, acceleration is constant and negative.

step_by_step.explanation: This matches an object thrown upward under gravity: starts with positive velocity, slows down, stops at max height, then accelerates downward.

problems.final_answer: The graph represents motion with constant negative acceleration, such as an object thrown vertically upward under the influence of gravity.

problems.problem: From the position-time graph of an object, the position at $t = 4$ s is 10 m, and at $t = 6$ s, the position is 30 m. Calculate the average velocity of the object between $t = 4$ s and $t = 6$ s.

step_by_step.explanation: Initial time $t_1 = 4$ s, position $x_1 = 10$ m. Final time $t_2 = 6$ s, position $x_2 = 30$ m.

problems.problem: From an acceleration-time graph, an object accelerates at $2 \, \text{m/s}^2$ for 3 seconds and then decelerates at $-2 \, \text{m/s}^2$ for 3 seconds. If the initial velocity is $5 \, \text{m/s}$, calculate the total distance traveled using the velocity-time graph method.

step_by_step.step: Construct velocity-time graph from acceleration data
step_by_step.explanation: Phase 1 (0-3 s): Acceleration = 2 m/s², so velocity increases linearly from 5 m/s to 11 m/s. Phase 2 (3-6 s): Deceleration = -2 m/s², so velocity decreases linearly from 11 m/s back to 5 m/s.

step_by_step.step: Identify trapezoid areas on v-t graph
step_by_step.explanation: Distance = area under v-t graph. The graph forms two trapezoids: first from t=0 to t=3 s, second from t=3 s to t=6 s.

problems.problem: A car starts from rest and reaches a velocity of 12 m/s in 5 seconds. It maintains this velocity for another 8 seconds and then decelerates to rest in 7 seconds. (a) Determine the total distance covered. (b) Determine the average speed.

step_by_step.explanation: The motion forms a trapezoid on v-t graph: acceleration phase (0-5 s), constant velocity phase (5-13 s), deceleration phase (13-20 s).

step_by_step.step: Calculate total distance using trapezoid area
step_by_step.calculation: Distance = area under v-t curve = $\frac{1}{2} \times (\text{top base} + \text{bottom base}) \times \text{height} = \frac{1}{2} \times (8 + 20) \times 12 = \frac{1}{2} \times 28 \times 12 = 168 \, \text{m}$

problems.final_answer: (a) Total distance = 168 m, (b) Average speed = 8.4 m/s

problems.problem: A cyclist is traveling at a constant speed of 15 m/s for 10 seconds. After that, he applies the brakes and decelerates at $-1.5 \, \text{m/s}^2$ for 6 seconds. (a) Determine the total distance covered during the entire motion. (b) Determine the average speed for the entire motion.

step_by_step.explanation: From t = 0 to 10 s: velocity = 15 m/s (constant).
From t = 10 to 16 s: initial velocity = 15 m/s, deceleration = -1.5 m/s², time = 6 s.

step_by_step.step: Calculate distance in phase 2 using trapezoid area

problems.final_answer: (a) Total distance = 213 m, (b) Average speed ≈ 13.31 m/s

problems.problem: A rock is thrown vertically upward from the edge of a cliff. It reaches a maximum height of 15 meters above the cliff before falling down to the bottom, which is 35 meters below the cliff. Determine the total distance traveled by the rock.

step_by_step.explanation: The rock starts at the cliff edge (reference point: cliff top = 0).

step_by_step.calculation: Rises 15 m above cliff: distance₁ = 15 m
Falls from max height back to cliff edge: distance₂ = 15 m
Falls from cliff edge to bottom (35 m below): distance₃ = 35 m

problems.problem: A rock is thrown vertically upward from the edge of a cliff. It reaches a maximum height of 15 meters above the cliff before falling down to the bottom, which is 35 meters below the cliff. Determine the displacement of the rock.

step_by_step.explanation: Let cliff edge be y = 0, upward positive.

step_by_step.calculation: Initial: y_i = 0 m (cliff edge). Final: y_f = -35 m (bottom below cliff).

step_by_step.explanation: Negative indicates downward displacement. Magnitude = 35 m.

problems.problem:
Can an object's average velocity equal zero when the object's speed is greater than zero?
A. Yes, when the object moves in a straight line at a constant rate
B. Yes, when the object returns to its original position
C. No, it is impossible because they are always equal
D. No, it is impossible because the magnitude of the velocity is always greater than speed

step_by_step.explanation: Average velocity = displacement / time. Speed = total distance / time.

step_by_step.step: Consider condition for zero average velocity
step_by_step.explanation: Displacement is zero if the object returns to its starting point.
Even if displacement is zero, the total distance traveled can be > 0 if the object moved somewhere and back.

step_by_step.calculation:
Example: Walk 10 m east then 10 m west, returning to start. Total time = 4 s.
Displacement = 0 → avg velocity = 0.
Total distance = 20 m → avg speed = 5 m/s (> 0).

step_by_step.explanation: A is false (constant speed in straight line → nonzero displacement). B matches (return to original position). C and D are false.

problems.problem: An object is thrown straight up with an initial velocity \( v_0 \). The graph represents the object's vertical displacement as a function of time. What is the total flying time of the object?

step_by_step.explanation: The displacement–time graph for projectile motion (vertical throw) is parabolic.
Launch is at t = 0, displacement = 0. Landing is when displacement returns to 0 (same vertical level as launch).

step_by_step.step: Read graph for time when displacement returns to zero
step_by_step.calculation: From graph: displacement crosses zero again at t = 8 s.

step_by_step.explanation: Total flying time = 8 s.

problems.problem: An object is thrown straight up with an initial velocity \( v_0 \). The graph represents the object's vertical displacement as a function of time. At what time does the object reach its maximum height?

step_by_step.explanation: For vertical throw, displacement-time graph is parabolic. Maximum height occurs when displacement is maximum.

step_by_step.step: Relate maximum height to graph features
step_by_step.explanation: Maximum height = peak of the parabola. At peak, slope (velocity) = 0.

step_by_step.calculation: From symmetry of projectile motion, time to max height = half of total flight time.

step_by_step.explanation: Graph shows total flight time = 8 s (displacement returns to zero at t = 8 s).

step_by_step.calculation: Time to max height = 8 s / 2 = 4 s.

problems.problem: An object is thrown straight up with an initial velocity $v_0$. The graph represents the object's vertical displacement as a function of time. What is the initial velocity $v_0$ of the object?

step_by_step.explanation: From graph: total flight time $T = 8$ s, so time to max height $t_{\text{up}} = 4$ s. Max height = peak displacement (read from graph).
Let's assume from graph that maximum height $H = 80$ m (typical example value; adjust if graph shows different). Using symmetry of vertical throw.

step_by_step.calculation: At max height, $v = 0$. Use $v = v_0 - gt_{\text{up}} \rightarrow 0 = v_0 - g(4)$.

step_by_step.explanation: Initial velocity $\approx 39.2$ m/s (or read exact from graph if H known).

problems.final_answer: Approximately 39.2 m/s (depending on max height from graph).

problems.problem: Which of the following graphs represents the velocity as a function of time of an object thrown straight up?

step_by_step.explanation: An object thrown straight up has constant downward acceleration $g$. Its velocity decreases linearly, becomes zero at the peak, then increases negatively (downward).
Velocity-time graph for constant acceleration is a straight line with negative slope ($a = -g$).
Graph should show: initial positive velocity, linear decrease to zero, then linear increase in negative direction (same magnitude slope).
Graph C matches this: positive start, crosses zero at peak time, then negative symmetric about time axis.

A: horizontal line (constant velocity) — incorrect.
B: velocity increases — incorrect (should decrease then become negative).
D: parabolic (displacement graph) — incorrect for velocity.

problems.problem: Which of the following graphs represents the acceleration as a function of time of an object thrown straight up?

step_by_step.explanation: For an object thrown straight up (ignoring air resistance), the only force acting is gravity, giving constant downward acceleration $a = -g$.
Constant acceleration means the graph is a horizontal line at $a = -9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2$.
Graph B shows a horizontal line below the time axis, representing constant negative acceleration.
Graphs showing changing slope, zero slope in one segment, or positive constant acceleration do not match free-fall under gravity.

problems.problem: The relationship between the position and time of a moving object is shown on the graph. Use this graph for the next two questions. What is the instantaneous speed of the object at 4 s?

step_by_step.explanation: The graph shows position vs. time. Instantaneous speed at a given time is the magnitude of the slope of the position-time graph at that point.

step_by_step.step: Examine graph segment near t = 4 s
step_by_step.explanation: From the given solution: the position is linear between t = 1 s (S = 2 m) and t = 4 s (S = 8 m).
Since the position-time graph is a straight line over this interval, the speed is constant and equals the slope.
At t = 4 s, the object is still on the same linear segment, so instantaneous speed = 2 m/s.

problems.problem:
During which of the following times does the object accelerate?
A. 0 s to 2 s
B. 2 s to 4 s
C. 0 s to 4 s
D. 4 s to 8 s

step_by_step.explanation: Acceleration occurs when velocity changes. On a position-time graph, velocity is the slope. Changing slope means acceleration.

step_by_step.step: Analyze slope from 0 s to 4 s
step_by_step.explanation: From 0 s to 4 s, the graph is a straight line with constant positive slope → constant velocity → acceleration = 0.

step_by_step.step: Analyze slope from 4 s to 8 s
step_by_step.explanation: From 4 s to 8 s, the graph's slope decreases (curve bends toward horizontal) → velocity is decreasing → negative acceleration (deceleration).

A, B, C are within 0–4 s → no acceleration.
D (4–8 s) → acceleration present (deceleration).
The object accelerates during 4 s to 8 s.

problems.problem: What is the acceleration at time $t = 1 \, \text{s}$?

step_by_step.explanation: From velocity-time graph: at $t = 0$ s, velocity $v_1 = 0$ m/s; at $t = 1$ s, velocity $v_2 = 2$ m/s.
Since velocity-time graph is a straight line here, acceleration is constant over this interval.

problems.problem: What is the acceleration at time $t = 8 \, \text{s}$?

step_by_step.step: Examine velocity-time graph near t = 8 s
step_by_step.explanation: From graph: between t = 7 s and t = 8 s, velocity is constant at $v = -4 \, \text{m/s}$.

step_by_step.calculation: Acceleration $a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}$. Here, $v_2 = -4 \, \text{m/s}$ at $t_2 = 8 \, \text{s}$, $v_1 = -4 \, \text{m/s}$ at $t_1 = 7 \, \text{s}$.

step_by_step.explanation: Constant velocity over an interval means zero acceleration at that time.

problems.problem: What is the acceleration at time $t = 6$ s?

step_by_step.step: Read velocities from graph near t = 6 s
step_by_step.explanation: From velocity-time graph: at $t = 5$ s, $v_1 = 4$ m/s; at $t = 6$ s, $v_2 = 0$ m/s.
Negative acceleration means deceleration—velocity is decreasing while moving in positive direction.
Between t = 5 s and t = 6 s, the v-t graph is a straight line with constant negative slope of $-4 \, \text{m/s}^2$.

problems.problem: What is the total displacement for the entire trip?

step_by_step.explanation: Displacement $= \text{area under $v$-$t$ graph}$. Positive velocity gives positive area, negative velocity gives negative area.

step_by_step.calculation:
From $t = 0$ to $6$ s: bases $3\ \text{m/s}$ and $6\ \text{m/s}$, height $4$ s.
$\text{Area}_A = \frac{1}{2}(3 + 6) \times 4 = 18\ \text{m}$.

From $t = 6$ to $10$ s: bases $2\ \text{m/s}$ and $4\ \text{m/s}$ (velocity negative), height $4$ s.
$\text{Area}_B = \frac{1}{2}(2 + 4) \times (-4) = -12\ \text{m}$.

step_by_step.explanation: Positive displacement means net movement is forward relative to starting point.

problems.problem: What is the total traveled distance for the entire trip?

step_by_step.step: Understand distance vs. displacement on $v$-$t$ graph
step_by_step.explanation: Distance = sum of absolute areas under $v$-$t$ graph (all areas taken as positive).

step_by_step.step: Calculate area of trapezoid A (first segment)
step_by_step.calculation:
From $t = 0$ to $6$ s: bases $3\ \text{m/s}$, $6\ \text{m/s}$, height $4$ s.
$\text{Area}_A = \frac{1}{2}(3 + 6) \times 4 = 18\ \text{m}$.

step_by_step.step: Calculate area of trapezoid B (second segment)
step_by_step.calculation:
From $t = 6$ to $10$ s: bases $2\ \text{m/s}$, $4\ \text{m/s}$, height $4$ s (using absolute value of velocity magnitudes).
$\text{Area}_B = \frac{1}{2}(2 + 4) \times 4 = 12\ \text{m}$.

step_by_step.step: Sum absolute areas for total distance

step_by_step.explanation: Distance is greater than displacement because object moved forward then backward; distance sums both movements.

problems.problem: A rock is thrown straight up with twice the initial velocity of another. How much higher will the first rock be at its apex?

step_by_step.explanation: For vertical throw: maximum height $h = \frac{v_0^2}{2g}$ (since $v_f^2 = v_0^2 - 2gh$, and at max height $v_f = 0$).

step_by_step.calculation:
Let $v_{02}$ = initial velocity of second rock.
First rock: $v_{01} = 2v_{02}$.

step_by_step.explanation: First rock reaches 4 times the height of the second rock.
Height is proportional to the square of initial velocity: doubling velocity quadruples height.

problems.problem:
Based on the position–time graph shown, a bicyclist moves along a straight line with an initial velocity $v_0$ and slows down. Which of the following best describes the signs set for the initial position, initial velocity, and acceleration?
A. Positive Positive Negative
B. Negative Positive Negative
C. Negative Negative Positive
D. Negative Negative Negative

step_by_step.explanation: At $t = 0$, $x \approx -10$ m → $x_0 < 0$ (negative).
Velocity vector points left (negative $x$-direction) → $v_0 < 0$ (negative).

Slowing down means acceleration opposes velocity.
Since $v_0 < 0$ (left), acceleration must point right → $a > 0$ (positive).
Signs: $x_0$ negative, $v_0$ negative, $a$ positive → Option C.

problems.problem: Vector $\mathbf{D}$ has components $D_x = 3\ \text{m}$ and $D_y = 4\ \text{m}$. (a) What is the x-component of vector $\mathbf{D}$? (b) What is the y-component of vector $\mathbf{D}$? (c) What is the magnitude of vector $\mathbf{D}$?

step_by_step.explanation: Given directly: $D_x = 3\ \text{m}$.
Given directly: $D_y = 4\ \text{m}$.

problems.problem: An object changes its velocity from $\vec{v}_1$ to $\vec{v}_2$ during a time interval $\Delta t$. Which of the following is the correct direction for the object's acceleration?

step_by_step.explanation: $\vec{a} = \frac{\Delta \vec{v}}{\Delta t}$, where $\Delta \vec{v} = \vec{v}_2 - \vec{v}_1$.
$\vec{v}_1$ points horizontally to the right, $\vec{v}_2$ points vertically upward.
Draw $\vec{v}_2$, then add $(-\vec{v}_1)$ (leftward). Resultant $\Delta \vec{v}$ points diagonally up and left.
Acceleration is parallel to $\Delta \vec{v}$, so $\vec{a}$ points diagonally up-left.
Option B matches 'diagonally upwards and to the left'.

problems.problem:
A projectile is fired at $60^\circ$ above the horizontal line with an initial velocity $v_0$. At which of the following angles will the projectile land at the same distance as it did in the first trial?
A. $20^\circ$
B. $30^\circ$
C. $40^\circ$
D. $45^\circ$

step_by_step.explanation: Range $R = \frac{v_0^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g}$.

step_by_step.step: Set ranges equal for two angles
step_by_step.explanation: $R_1 = R_2$ → $\sin(2\theta_1) = \sin(2\theta_2)$.
$\theta_1 = 60^\circ$ → $2\theta_1 = 120^\circ$, so $\sin(120^\circ) = \sin(60^\circ) = \sqrt{3}/2$.
Property: $\sin(\alpha) = \sin(180^\circ - \alpha)$. Thus $2\theta_2 = 180^\circ - 120^\circ = 60^\circ$ → $\theta_2 = 30^\circ$.
$\sin(120^\circ) = \sin(60^\circ)$ only. Since $0^\circ < 2\theta_2 < 180^\circ$, the only solution in given options is $\theta_2 = 30^\circ$.

problems.problem:
When a projectile reaches the highest point, the vertical component of the acceleration is:
A. Greater than g
B. Positive g
C. Negative g
D. Zero

step_by_step.explanation: At the apex, vertical velocity $v_y = 0$, but the object is still under influence of gravity.
Gravity is constant: $a_y = -g$, where $g \approx 9.8\ \text{m/s}^2$ downward.

step_by_step.step: Check if acceleration changes at apex
step_by_step.explanation: Acceleration is constant throughout projectile motion (neglecting air resistance). It does not vanish or change magnitude at the top.

step_by_step.step: Determine sign in standard coordinate system
step_by_step.explanation: If upward is positive, acceleration downward is negative: $a_y = -g$.
Negative $g$ corresponds to option C.

problems.problem:
When a projectile reaches the highest point, the horizontal component of the acceleration is:
A. Less than g
B. Positive g
C. Negative g
D. Zero

step_by_step.explanation: Neglecting air resistance, only force is gravity, which acts vertically downward.
No horizontal force → horizontal acceleration $a_x = 0$ throughout motion.
At apex, vertical velocity is zero, but horizontal motion remains unchanged — still $a_x = 0$.
Zero horizontal acceleration corresponds to option D.

problems.problem: An object accelerates from rest at a constant rate. Which of the following graphs could be used to describe the motion of the object? (Select all the options that are correct)

step_by_step.step: Interpret 'accelerates from rest at constant rate'
step_by_step.explanation: From rest: $v_0 = 0$. Constant acceleration: $a$ is constant and nonzero.
Constant $a$ → $x(t) = \frac12 a t^2$ (parabola). Options with linear $x$-$t$ or curves not matching $t^2$ are incorrect.
$v(t) = at$ (straight line through origin with slope $a$). Correct option: positive slope line from origin (B).
$a$ constant → horizontal line (D).
Options show various $x$-$t$, $v$-$t$, $a$-$t$ shapes. Only B ($v$-$t$: linear through origin) and D ($a$-$t$: horizontal line) match constant acceleration from rest.

problems.problem:
A projectile is launched from point A with an initial speed $v_0$ at an angle $\theta$ to the horizontal. It follows a symmetrical parabolic path, reaching maximum height at point C and returning to the same horizontal level at point E. Points B and D are at equal heights on the upward and downward paths, respectively.

Which of the following statements about the projectile motion are correct? (Select all the options that are correct)

step_by_step.step: Interpret statement A: 'The vertical component of the velocity at point C is $v_0 \sin(\theta)$'
step_by_step.explanation: At the maximum height (point C), the projectile momentarily has zero vertical velocity because it stops rising and begins to fall. Therefore, the vertical component is 0, not $v_0 \sin(\theta)$. Statement A is false.

step_by_step.step: Interpret statement B: 'The horizontal component of the velocity at point C is $v_0 \cos(\theta)$'
step_by_step.explanation: The horizontal velocity remains constant in ideal projectile motion (no air resistance). Thus, at all points including C, the horizontal component is $v_0 \cos(\theta)$. Statement B is true.

step_by_step.step: Interpret statement C: 'The projectile travels with the same speed at point B and D'
step_by_step.explanation: B and D are at the same height. Due to symmetry, the vertical speeds at these points are equal in magnitude (but opposite in direction), and horizontal speeds are equal. Hence, the total speed (magnitude of velocity) is the same at B and D. Statement C is true.

step_by_step.step: Interpret statement D: 'The acceleration at point C is zero'
step_by_step.explanation: The only acceleration acting on the projectile is due to gravity, which is constant and downward throughout the motion. Even at the highest point, acceleration is $g$ downward, not zero. Statement D is false.

problems.problem: Position as a function of time of two moving objects is presented by the graph. Which of the following statements is true?

step_by_step.explanation: Velocity is given by the slope of the position-time graph. The steeper the slope, the greater the velocity.

step_by_step.step: Compare slopes of Object I and Object II
step_by_step.explanation: The graph shows that Object II has a steeper slope than Object I at all times, meaning Object II has a greater velocity.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement A: 'Object I has a greater velocity than object II'
step_by_step.explanation: False. Object I's slope is less steep, so its velocity is lower than that of Object II.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement B: 'Object II has a greater velocity than object I'
step_by_step.explanation: True. The steeper slope of Object II indicates a higher velocity.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement C: 'At time $t_0$ they have the same velocity'
step_by_step.explanation: False. At $t_0$, their slopes are different, so their velocities are different. They only share the same position at that instant, not the same speed.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement D: 'At time $t_0$ object II passes by object I'
step_by_step.explanation: True. At $t_0$, their position curves intersect, meaning Object II overtakes Object I at that moment.

problems.problem:
Position as a function of time of a moving object is presented by the graph. Which of the following is true about the type of motion?

A. The object moves with a constant positive acceleration
B. The object moves with a constant positive velocity
C. The slope of this graph is equal to the object's acceleration
D. The slope of this graph is equal to the object's velocity

step_by_step.step: Identify graph type and its meaning
step_by_step.explanation: The graph shows position (displacement) versus time. The slope of this graph represents velocity, not acceleration.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement A: 'The object moves with a constant positive acceleration'
step_by_step.explanation: False. A straight line in a position-time graph indicates constant velocity, not acceleration. Acceleration is zero here.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement B: 'The object moves with a constant positive velocity'
step_by_step.explanation: True. A straight line with a positive slope means the object is moving forward with constant speed (uniform velocity).

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement C: 'The slope of this graph is equal to the object's acceleration'
step_by_step.explanation: False. In a position-time graph, the slope gives velocity, not acceleration. Acceleration is the slope of a velocity-time graph.

step_by_step.step: Analyze statement D: 'The slope of this graph is equal to the object's velocity'
step_by_step.explanation: True. By definition, the slope of a position-time graph is the velocity of the object.

problems.problem:
The diagram represents a swimmer. The swimmer is capable of swimming in still water with a velocity $V_1 = 1\, \text{m/s}$. He aims directly across a 100 m wide river, where the river’s current has a velocity $V_2 = 2\, \text{m/s}$.

How much time will it take for the swimmer to cross the river?

step_by_step.explanation: The swimmer’s velocity $V_1$ is directed perpendicular to the riverbank. The river current $V_2$ is parallel to the riverbank and does not affect the motion across the river because the two velocities are perpendicular.

step_by_step.step: Determine the relevant velocity for crossing
step_by_step.explanation: The time to cross depends only on the velocity component perpendicular to the riverbank, which is $V_1 = 1\, \text{m/s}$.

step_by_step.step: Apply the time formula for uniform motion
step_by_step.explanation: The time $t$ to cross the river is given by $t = \frac{\text{width}}{V_1} = \frac{100\, \text{m}}{1\, \text{m/s}} = 100\, \text{s}$.
The current $V_2$ will cause the swimmer to drift downstream, but it does not affect the time to cross the river, since perpendicular motions are independent.

problems.problem:
The diagram represents a swimmer. The swimmer is capable of swimming in still water with a velocity $V_1 = 1\, \text{m/s}$. He aims directly across a 100 m wide river, where the river's current has a velocity $V_2 = 2\, \text{m/s}$.

How far downstream will he land?

step_by_step.step: Determine the time to cross the river
step_by_step.explanation: The swimmer's velocity across the river is $V_1 = 1\, \text{m/s}$ and the river width is $100\, \text{m}$. The crossing time is $t = \frac{100\, \text{m}}{1\, \text{m/s}} = 100\, \text{s}$.
The river current flows downstream at $V_2 = 2\, \text{m/s}$ parallel to the riverbank.
During the crossing time $t = 100\, \text{s}$, the current displaces the swimmer downstream by a distance $d_{\text{down}} = V_2 \times t = 2\, \text{m/s} \times 100\, \text{s} = 200\, \text{m}$.

Because the swimmer aims directly across and the current is perpendicular to his swimming direction, his downstream displacement is independent of his swimming direction and only depends on the current speed and crossing time.

problems.problem:
The diagram represents a swimmer. The swimmer is capable of swimming in still water with a velocity $V_1 = 1\, \text{m/s}$. He aims directly across a 100 m wide river, where the river's current has a velocity $V_2 = 2\, \text{m/s}$.

What is the velocity of the swimmer relative to the riverbank?

step_by_step.step: Identify the motion components relative to the riverbank
step_by_step.explanation: The swimmer’s velocity relative to still water is $V_1 = 1\, \text{m/s}$ directly across the river. The river current flows downstream at $V_2 = 2\, \text{m/s}$ parallel to the riverbank. These two velocities are perpendicular.

step_by_step.step: Apply vector addition for perpendicular components
step_by_step.explanation: The swimmer’s total velocity relative to the riverbank is the vector sum of $\vec{V}_1$ and $\vec{V}_2$. Since they are perpendicular, the magnitude is found using the Pythagorean theorem: $V_{\text{total}} = \sqrt{V_1^2 + V_2^2}$.
$V_{\text{total}} = \sqrt{(1\, \text{m/s})^2 + (2\, \text{m/s})^2} = \sqrt{1 + 4} = \sqrt{5}\, \text{m/s} \approx 2.236\, \text{m/s}$.

The resultant velocity is at an angle downstream from the directly-across direction, with $\tan \theta = \frac{V_2}{V_1} = 2$, so $\theta \approx 63.4^\circ$ relative to the line perpendicular to the riverbank.

problems.final_answer: $\sqrt{5}$ m/s (approximately 2.24 m/s) at an angle downstream from the directly-across direction

problems.problem:
The graphs above represent the position, velocity, and acceleration as a function of time for a marble moving in one dimension. Which of the following could describe the motion of the marble?

A. Rolling along the floor and then bouncing off a wall.
B. Rolling down one side of a bowl and then rolling up the other side.
C. Rolling up a ramp and then rolling back down.
D. Falling and then bouncing elastically off a hard floor.

step_by_step.explanation: Cup-shaped parabola starting and ending at 0, with a negative peak. This means the object starts at the origin, moves in the negative direction to a farthest point, then returns to the origin.

Straight line from negative to positive with positive slope. Initially velocity is negative (moving in the negative direction), it increases smoothly through zero (object stops), then becomes positive (moves in the positive direction).

Constant negative value. This means the acceleration is constant and directed opposite to the positive direction (i.e., in the negative direction). Since the velocity graph shows velocity increasing from negative to positive, this constant negative acceleration is actually decelerating the object while it moves negatively, bringing it to rest, then accelerating it in the positive direction.

The object starts with an initial velocity in the negative direction. A constant negative acceleration acts opposite to that motion, slowing it down, stopping it, and then speeding it up in the positive direction. The position symmetrically returns to the starting point.

A (bouncing off a wall): involves a sudden velocity reversal, not smooth. ❌
B (rolling in a bowl): acceleration would vary with position, not be constant. ❌
C (rolling up a ramp then back down): constant acceleration component along the ramp under gravity; initial velocity up the ramp (negative if down is positive), constant acceleration down the ramp (negative if up is positive) matches signs; smooth turnaround fits. ✅
D (falling and bouncing): involves a sudden bounce, not smooth velocity change. ❌

problems.problem: A car travels along a straight road with constant acceleration from rest. It passes a checkpoint at 60 m/s after 10 seconds of acceleration. What was its acceleration during this time, and what distance did it travel in that time?

step_by_step.explanation: Initial velocity $u = 0$ m/s (from rest), final velocity $v = 60$ m/s, time $t = 10$ s, acceleration $a$ is constant and unknown, distance $d$ is unknown.

step_by_step.step: Use the velocity-time kinematic equation to find acceleration
Use the displacement-time kinematic equation to find distance

step_by_step.explanation: The car accelerates at $6\text{ m/s}^2$ and travels $300$ meters in the $10$-second interval.

problems.problem:
An object's velocity $v$ as a function of time $t$ is given in the graph above. Which of the following statements is true about the motion of the object?

(A) The object is not moving from $t = 4$ to $t = 10$ s.
(B) The object's initial and final positions are the same.
(C) The object is slowing down from $t = 14$ s to $t = 16$ s.
(D) The average acceleration of the object from $t = 0$ s to $t = 4$ s is different from the acceleration from $t = 34$ s to $t = 36$ s.

step_by_step.step: Calculate total displacement from velocity-time graph
step_by_step.explanation: First trapezoid (t = 0–14 s): bases = 6 s and 14 s, height = 10 m/s → area = 100 m. Second trapezoid (t = 14–36 s): bases = 18 s and 22 s, height = -5 m/s → area = -100 m. Total displacement = 0 m.
Zero net displacement means the object ends at its starting position → (B) is true.

step_by_step.step: Check statement (C): slowing down from t = 14 s to 16 s
step_by_step.explanation: At t = 14 s, v = 0 m/s. At t = 16 s, v = -5 m/s. Speed increases from 0 to 5 m/s → object is speeding up in the negative direction, not slowing down. (C) is false.

(A): Velocity is greater than 0 and constant between t = 4 s and t = 10 s → object is moving. False.
(D): From t = 0–4 s, \( a = 2.5\ \text{m/s}^2 \). From t = 34–36 s, \( a = 2.5\ \text{m/s}^2 \). Accelerations are equal → False.
Only statement (B) is true based on zero total displacement.

problems.problem:
A diver initially moving horizontally with speed $v$ dives off the edge of a vertical cliff and lands in the water a distance $d$ from the base of the cliff. How far from the base of the cliff would the diver have landed if the diver initially had been moving horizontally with speed $2v$?

(A) $d$
(B) $\sqrt{2}d$
(C) $2d$
(D) $4d$

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal and vertical motions are independent. The time of flight depends only on vertical free fall, not horizontal speed.
Time to fall from height $h$: $t = \sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}$, which is the same regardless of horizontal speed.

step_by_step.step: Relate horizontal distance to initial speed
step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal distance $d = v \cdot t$. If initial horizontal speed is doubled to $2v$, new horizontal distance = $(2v) \cdot t = 2(vt) = 2d$.
Horizontal distance is directly proportional to initial horizontal speed when time of flight is constant → answer is $2d$.

problems.problem:
A body moving in the positive x direction passes the origin at time t = 0. Between t = 0 and t = 1 second, the body has a constant speed of 24 meters per second. At t = 1 second, the body is given a constant acceleration of 6 meters per second squared in the negative x direction. The position x of the body at t = 11 seconds is

(A) +99m
(B) +36m
(C) -36m
(D) -99m

step_by_step.step: Motion from t = 0 to t = 1 s (constant velocity)
step_by_step.explanation: Body moves with $v = 24\ \text{m/s}$. Distance: $x_1 = v \cdot t = 24 \times 1 = 24\ \text{m}$. At t = 1 s, position = +24 m.

step_by_step.step: Motion from t = 1 s to t = 11 s (constant acceleration)
step_by_step.explanation:
Initial velocity at t = 1 s: $v_0 = 24\ \text{m/s}$. Acceleration $a = -6\ \text{m/s}^2$. Time interval: $t = 10\ \text{s}$.
Use $x_2 = v_0 t + \frac12 a t^2 = 24 \times 10 + \frac12 (-6)(10^2) = 240 - 300 = -60\ \text{m}$.
Negative position means the body is 36 meters in the negative x direction from the origin.

problems.problem:
Two automobiles are 150 kilometers apart and traveling toward each other. One automobile is moving at 60 km/h and the other is moving at 40 km/h. In how many hours will they meet?

(A) 1.5
(B) 1.75
(C) 2.0
(D) 2.5

step_by_step.explanation: The cars start 150 km apart and move toward each other. Their speeds add because they are closing the gap together.
Relative speed = speed₁ + speed₂ = 60 km/h + 40 km/h = 100 km/h.
Time = distance / relative speed = 150 km / 100 km/h = 1.5 hours.
They meet after 1.5 hours of travel.

problems.problem:
Questions 50–53 relate to two objects that start at x = 0 at t = 0 and move in one dimension independently of one another. Graphs of the velocity of each object versus time are shown below.

Which object is farthest from the origin at t = 2 seconds?

(a) A
(b) B
(c) They are in the same location at t = 2 seconds
(d) They are the same distance from the origin, but in opposite directions

step_by_step.explanation: From t = 0 to t = 1 s, v = +1 m/s → displacement = 1 m. From t = 1 to t = 2 s, v = −1 m/s → displacement = −1 m. Total displacement = 0 m → Object A returns to origin at t = 2 s.

Object B’s velocity is always positive and increases over time (nonlinear, accelerating). The area under its v–t curve from t = 0 to t = 2 s is greater than 0 and greater than the magnitude of Object A’s net displacement.
Distance from origin = |displacement|. Object A: displacement = 0. Object B: displacement > 0. Therefore, Object B is farther from the origin.
(c) False — different locations. (d) False — A is at origin, B is positive; not same distance.

problems.problem:
Which object moves with constant non-zero acceleration?

(A) A
(B) B
(C) both A and B
(D) neither A nor B

step_by_step.step: Recall acceleration from a velocity-time graph
step_by_step.explanation: Acceleration is the slope of the v–t graph. Constant non-zero acceleration means a straight line with a non-zero slope.

Object A’s graph has two horizontal segments (zero slope) connected by an instantaneous jump at t = 1 s. There is no extended interval with constant non-zero slope → no constant non-zero acceleration.
Object B’s graph is a smooth curve with a steadily increasing slope, indicating velocity increases at a constant rate → constant positive acceleration.
Only Object B has constant non-zero acceleration.

problems.problem:
Which object is in its initial position at \( t = 2 \) seconds?

(A) A
(B) B
(C) both A and B
(D) neither A nor B

step_by_step.step: Recall: position change = area under v–t graph
step_by_step.explanation: The object is in its initial position if net displacement from t = 0 to t = 2 s is zero.
From t = 0–1 s: v = +1 m/s → area = +1 m. From t = 1–2 s: v = −1 m/s → area = −1 m. Net displacement = 0 m → returns to start.
Object B’s velocity is always positive (v > 0), so area under curve from t = 0–2 s > 0. Net displacement > 0 → not back at initial position.
Only Object A has zero net displacement → only A is back at initial position.

problems.problem: The graph above shows the velocity versus time for an object moving in a straight line. At what time after t = 0 does the object again pass through its initial position?

step_by_step.explanation: The object passes through its initial position when the net displacement (total area under v–t curve) returns to zero.

step_by_step.step: Calculate displacement from t = 0 to t = 1 s
step_by_step.explanation: Triangle area: base = 1 s, height = –1 m/s. Area = 0.5 × 1 × (–1) = –0.5 m. Net displacement after 1 s = –0.5 m.

step_by_step.step: Calculate additional displacement needed to return to start
step_by_step.explanation: To cancel –0.5 m, the next positive area must total +0.5 m.

step_by_step.step: Analyze positive velocity segment after t = 1 s
step_by_step.explanation: From t = 1 s onward, v becomes positive. The area under the curve from t = 1 s until the return time must sum to +0.5 m.

step_by_step.step: Check between t = 1 s and t = 2 s
step_by_step.explanation: If v increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s over 1 s, the area from t = 1 s to some t between 1 and 2 s can be calculated. When the positive area reaches exactly 0.5 m, the object returns to start.
Given solution states: first positive area = 0.25 m (triangle 0 to 0.5 s after t = 1 s), then additional area = 0.25 m → total = 0.5 m. This occurs before t = 2 s → time between 1 s and 2 s.
